column1: Epiglottitis is inflammation of the epiglottis.
The epiglottis is a stiff, yet flexible tissue (called cartilage) at the back of the tongue.
Swelling of the epiglottis is usually caused by the bacteria Haemophilus influenzae (H. influenzae).
It may also be due to other bacteria or viruses that can cause upper respiratory infections.
The disease was once most often seen in children ages 2 through 6.
In rare cases, epiglottitis can occur in adults.

Other symptoms may include: - Abnormal breathing sounds (stridor) - Fever - Blue skin color (cyanosis) - Drooling - Difficulty breathing (patient may need to sit upright and lean slightly forward to breathe) - Difficulty swallowing - Voice changes (hoarseness) The airways can become totally blocked, which can result in cardiac arrest and death.

Treatment involves methods to help the person breathe, including: - Breathing tube (intubation) - Moistened (humidified) oxygen Other treatments may include: - Antibiotics to treat the infection - Anti-inflammatory medicines, called corticosteroids, to decrease throat swelling - Fluids given through a vein (by IV)
The most common bacteria (H. influenzae) that causes epiglottitis is contagious.
